mali2kaks.py - rate analysis with PAML¶

Author:Andreas Heger
Release:$Id$
Date:April 02, 2014
Tags:Python

Purpose¶

This script will do pairwise rate analysis on a set of multiply aligned sequences in fasta format.

PAML bails if sequences in a multiple alignment are not overlapping. Thus this code checks for each pair the overlap. If a pair is not overlapping, it goes into pairwise mode.

Usage¶

Example:

python mali2kaks.py --help

Type:

python mali2kaks.py --help

for command line help.

Command line options¶

Usage: mali2kaks.py [options]

Options:
  --version             show program's version number and exit
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
  --no-usage            output help without usage information
  --set-omega=OMEGA     initial omega value.
  --set-kappa=KAPPA     initial kappa value.
  --fix-kappa           do not estimate kappa.
  --fix-omega           do not estimate omega.
  --set-codon-frequencies=CODON_FREQUENCIES
                        set codon frequencies.
  --set-method=PAML_METHOD
                        set paml optimization method [0|1].
  --set-sequence-type=SEQTYPE
                        sequence type.
  --set-clean-data=CLEAN_DATA
                        PAML should cleanup data:  0=only gaps within pair are
                        removed, 1=columns in the mali with gaps are removed.
  --dump                dump raw output [False].
  --set-optimization-threshold=OPTIMIZATION_THRESHOLD
                        set paml optimization threshold [none].
  -i INPUT_FORMAT, --input-format=INPUT_FORMAT
                        input format of multiple alignment [fasta].
  --pairwise            force pairwise comparison [False].
  --iteration=ITERATION
                        iteration mode [all-vs-all].
  --no-clean            do not clean multiple alignment before submitting to
                        codeml. It might take too long for very large
                        sequences.
  --method=METHOD       choose method for rate computation [paml]
  --xrate-model=XRATE_MODEL
                        models to use [f3x4-four].
  -w WRITE, --write=WRITE
                        output sections to write [[]].
  -o OUTPUT_PATTERN, --output-pattern=OUTPUT_PATTERN
                        output pattern for output files [%s.eg].
  --xrate-insert-frequencies
                        estimate codon frequencies from input [False].
  --xrate-uniform-frequencies
                        use uniform codon frequencies [False].
  --xrate-fix-frequencies
                        set initial frequencies to const [False].
  --xrate-estimate-frequencies
                        estimate nucleotide frequencies [False].
  --xrate-fix-rates=FIX_RATES
                        fix rates to specified values. Note that the number of
                        rates has to match the ones
                        in the model. Provide values in a comma-separated list
                        [none].
  --xrate-min-increment=XRATE_MIN_INCREMENT
                        minimum increment to stop iteration in xrate [1e-06].
  --min-overlap=MIN_OVERLAP
                        minimum overlap between a sequence pair in residues
                        [60].
  --with-rho            output rho values (substitution rates per codon). This
                        requires a patched version of PAML [False].
  --with-counts         output counts of aligned positions, transitions and
                        transversions [False].
  --remove-stops        remove stop codons [False].
  --replicates=REPLICATES
                        in benchmarking mode expect ## replicates [none].
  --tree=TREE           use tree for estimation [none].
  -v LOGLEVEL, --verbose=LOGLEVEL
                        loglevel [1]. The higher, the more output.
  --timeit=TIMEIT_FILE  store timeing information in file [none].
  --timeit-name=TIMEIT_NAME
                        name in timing file for this class of jobs [all].
  --timeit-header       add header for timing information [none].
  --random-seed=RANDOM_SEED
                        random seed to initialize number generator with
                        [none].
  -I FILE, --stdin=FILE
                        file to read stdin from [default = stdin].
  -L FILE, --log=FILE   file with logging information [default = stdout].
  -E FILE, --error=FILE
                        file with error information [default = stderr].
  -S FILE, --stdout=FILE
                        file where output is to go [default = stdout].
